Reference Text: <S ssid="1" sid="1">The extensive use of Multiword Expressions (MWE) in natural language texts prompts more detailed studies that aim for a more adequate treatment of these expressions.</S><S ssid="1" sid="8">Calzolari et al.</S>
<S ssid="1" sid="68">In this work, we focused on MWEs composed of exactly two words (i.e. bigrams).</S><S ssid="1" sid="97">Formed by 568 MWEs, the fourth dictionary will be called D4.</S>

<S ssid="1" sid="217">This work consists in investigating the impact of Multiword Expressions on applications, focusing on compound nouns in Information Retrieval systems, and whether a more adequate treatment for these expressions can bring possible improvements in the indexing these expressions.</S><S ssid="1" sid="15">In this paper, we perform an application-oriented evaluation of the inclusion of MWE treatment into an Information Retrieval (IR) system.</S>

<S ssid="1" sid="3">Intuitively, with the appropriate treatment of MWEs, the results of an Information Retrieval (IR) system could be improved.</S><S ssid="1" sid="0">Identification and Treatment of Multiword Expressions applied to Information Retrieval</S><S ssid="1" sid="37">For our experiments, we used some standard statistical measures such as mutual information, point- wise mutual information, chi-square, permutation entropy (Zhang et al., 2006), dice coefficient, and t-test to extract MWEs from a collection of documents (i.e. we consider the collection of documents indexed by the IR system as our corpus).</S>

<S ssid="1" sid="1">The extensive use of Multiword Expressions (MWE) in natural language texts prompts more detailed studies that aim for a more adequate treatment of these expressions.</S><S ssid="1" sid="6">One of the motivations of this work is to investigate if the identification and appropriate treatment of Multiword Expressions (MWEs) in an application contributes to improve results and ultimately lead to more precise man-machine interaction.</S>

<S ssid="1" sid="217">This work consists in investigating the impact of Multiword Expressions on applications, focusing on compound nouns in Information Retrieval systems, and whether a more adequate treatment for these expressions can bring possible improvements in the indexing these expressions.</S>

<S ssid="1" sid="3">Intuitively, with the appropriate treatment of MWEs, the results of an Information Retrieval (IR) system could be improved.</S><S ssid="1" sid="217">This work consists in investigating the impact of Multiword Expressions on applications, focusing on compound nouns in Information Retrieval systems, and whether a more adequate treatment for these expressions can bring possible improvements in the indexing these expressions.</S>
